com.jacobschneider.engine.math.geometry

Interface Primitive

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    Primitives.Circle, Primitives.OpenCylinder, Primitives.Sphere, Primitives.Triangle

    public interface Primitive
    Interface for a primitive object. A primitive object is the lowest level collidable object in the engine. All implementations of this interface should be immutable. Any implementation that can define getSegments() and intersectSegment(Segment) is a valid primitive. A Shape object is made up of a set of these primitives.
    Author:
    Jacob

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Vector3 getNormal()
      Most primitives are a subset of a plane and have a well defined constant normal direction.
      List<Segment> getSegments()
      Generates a list of all segments that make up this primitive.
      Collision.CollisionInterface intersectSegment(Segment s)
      Returns the CollisionInterface that occurs between a segment and this primitive.

    • Method Detail

      • intersectSegment

        Collision.CollisionInterface intersectSegment(Segment s)
        Returns the CollisionInterface that occurs between a segment and this primitive. If no collision exists returns null.
        Parameters:
        s - A segment object
        Returns:
        The Collision.CollisionInterface or null that represents the intersection of the segment and this primitive.

      • getSegments

        List<Segment> getSegments()
        Generates a list of all segments that make up this primitive. If your primitive had hard edges, every outer edge must have a segment returned here. If your primitive has rounded edges you must return enough segments to define the boundary of your object to your satisfaction. Consider accepting a parameter to determine accuracy and making the number of edges dynamic.
        Returns:
        All the segments that make up this primitive.

      • getNormal

        Vector3 getNormal()
        Most primitives are a subset of a plane and have a well defined constant normal direction. If this is true return that normal direction. If not return null. Implementing this is not required and is used for performance purposes only.
        Returns:
        The constant normal vector of this primitive or null
